goal:
Social Purpose:

The association organises and facilitates collaborative investigation, scholarship and advocacy focused on examining, raising awareness of, and activating internal imperatives and processes of self-regulation that can oblige state and non-state actors to construct and manage their dealings with third parties in a manner that both accords with and serves to propagate their own observance of international law.

The association's primary activities are focused on analysing actors' construction and management of such dealings and are carried out in dialogue with their relevant authorities and decision-makers. Other activities are dedicated to methodological reflection, on processes of self-regulation and activation of particular interest to the association's members and colleagues. These two sets of activities draw on members' backgrounds in law, trade, economics and cognitive theory and are animated by their common commitments to human rights and conflict prevention.
interests: Budget, Competition, Consumers, Customs, European Neighbourhood Policy, External Relations, Humanitarian aid and civil protection, Institutional affairs, International co-operation and development, Justice and Fundamental Rights, Research and innovation, Single market, Taxation, Trade
euInitiatives:
Technical research is currently underway examining whether or how, for a range of EU external dealings, EU legislation is applied, and EU activities are implemented, consistently with EU positions and commitments in conformity with international law, as per the Treaty on the European Union article 21 (3bis) and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union article 7 (requiring consistency between EU activities and policies).

Our research accordingly examines the intersection between:
(a) the Common Foreign and Security Policy vis-à-vis the following countries or territories involved in belligerent occupations, and non self-governing territories: Azerbaijan (Nagorno-Karabakh) - Armenia; Cyprus - Turkey; Georgia (Abkhazia and South Ossetia) - Russian Federation; Palestine (the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip) - Israel; Syria (Golan Heights) – Israel; Ukraine (Crimea) - Russian Federation; and Western Sahara - Morocco

and

(b) the following policy areas: Agriculture and rural development, Budget, Data protection, European Neighbourhood Policy, Humanitarian aid and civil protection, International cooperation and development, Justice and fundamental rights, Single market and consumer protection, and Trade.

The findings of this research will be discussed with various responsible EU institutional and Member States actors in the course of this coming year.
